Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: How Moving Ears and Nose Helps Bats Understand Sound
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bats use echolocation to navigate without the aid of sight, using their nostrils and ears as a sonar system to fly and hunt in a cluttered environment. No current human-made sonar can reproduce this. Many bat species have been observed to move their ears and noseleaf (a structure which sits atop the nostrils) as they echolocate. This research will investigate how this motion effects how bats interpret echo signals in the brain. The species to be studied, the greater horseshoe bat, is native to China and has been shown to have a particularly efficient "bio-sonar." This research will be conducted in collaboration with Professor Hiroshi Riquimaroux at Shandong University in Jinan, China, who has expertise in the study of physiology of hearing, particularly in bats.

The study will observe how motion in the pinna and noseleaf structures during echolocation influences how the brain encodes auditory signals. A population of Rhinolophus and Hipposiderus bats, two species native to China, will be tethered while performing various sensing tasks. The local field potential responses will be recorded to determine the overall effects of dynamics of anatomical structures. The responses after a sensing task will be recorded to observe how motion specifically effects signaling in the superior and inferior colliculi. The study will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Hiroshi Riquimaroux at Shandong University in Jinan, China. He is a neuroscientist with expertise in the field of acoustics and the auditory system.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes Program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by the NSF and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project to obtain a better understanding of the echolocation of horseshoe bats (Rhinolophus ferrumequinum). Specifically project looked to link the motions of this species of bat’s pinna and noseleaf structures to different sensing and vocal responses. R. ferrumequinum, like the other species in the Rhinolophid family rapidly (within 200 ms) moves structures on the nostrils (known as the noseleaf) and ears during echolocation. It is believed this is an adaptation that allows this species to navigate in particularly dense, cluttered environments but it is unclear as to the mechanisms of how the different components of the bats’ biosonar system, i.e. pulse emission, ear motion, and neurological response to auditory stimuli, are related.

This work was done in collaboration with Shandong University in Jinan as part of the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes (EAPSI) program.

The work was to be done by recording the responses to differing sound stimuli. There were three different ways in which the data was recorded: recording the motions of the bat with a camera, recording the sonar pulses from the bat via a microphone placed approximately 10 cm in front of the bat, and recording the neural responses from the bat from the inferior colliculus, a structure located in the midbrain which has been identified as a crucial component of the mammalian auditory system. Data was analyzed in a variety of ways, a spike sorting paradigm was used to differentiate between sensing events in the neural data, a method was designed to sort different patterns of emission pulses from each other, and video data was matched on a frame-by-frame basis to the audio and neurophysiological data. Each of the different types of data were cross referenced against the other in order to find possible correlations between different components of the bats’ biosonar system

At this time no significant conclusions can be made regarding correlations with any of the auditory brainstem responses collected. Microphone and video data however indicated a possible link between different motions and different vocal patterns. In several cases, the video showed a very similar motion pattern of the ear as a certain vocal pattern was being emitted from the bat. Continuing work in collaboration with Shandong University will look to classify different vocal patterns and motions and see if there is a link between these classes. This will also further the developments on work in Virginia Tech at a biomimetic sonar system in which the sonar elements take inspiration from the species studied here. In this case, instead of sending the same pulse with the same motion each time, the sonar can be configured to move the ears in the different motion patterns observed in the bat as well as emitting different patterns of pulses also observed from this projects’ experiments; it can then be observed how different combinations of the motion and emission pulses affect the echoes; in particular what physical properties of the sound are being changed.

This work looks to better understand the underlying physical mechanisms behind echolocation and the correlation between different components of the bats biosonar system; pulse emission, dynamic ear motion, and neural responses to auditory stimuli in the case of this project. Doing this allows us a better understanding of how bats, with relatively few “emitters” and “sensors” are able to efficiently navigate and hunt in a cluttered, noisy environment. Very little is known about the neural basis of how echolocation works, especially in horseshoe bats and similar species which are particularly known for fast ear and noseleaf motions. In a broader since, this project looks to understand the neural circuitry between sensing and motor systems, and how each informs the other. From an engineering perspective, this can translate into smaller more efficient sensing systems, which allow for more mobile systems with better navigation abilities, especially underwater vehicles where sensing conventions such as light detection and ranging (LIDAR) are not usable due to the refractive properties of water.
